text: Bottle from beer[malade]. Dark amber color with huge beige head.Aroma of caramel, dark malt,chocolate, gingerbread. Taste, dark malt,chocolate, cherries, other fruits, caramel. Tasty.

brown colour with big head, big aroma ,sweet, fruits ,some spices, ok but not my
cup of tea
Draft at Beertemple, Amsterdam. Pours dark brown with a beige head. Aroma of cherries, red fruits, caramel, malts. Taste is light tart, moderate sweet, bitterness towards the end and after. Not bad.
LEDER & SPICE GOTT ERHALTÂ’S!!! A LOVER !!! :OOOO. Die dicke Jolle wartet im Keller.....auch hier werde ich berichten ;)... Fass. 15cl/3,25. BEER TEMPLE Amsterdam.

750 mL bottle shared by ebone1988. The pour is a darker brown/light black with a thicker light khaki head and a lot of soapy lace as it falls down to a thick collar and film. The aroma is definitely heavy on spicy rye. There is a bit of chocolate malt and a light roastiness. ItÂ’s got a little bit of a Porter thing going on that IÂ’m definitely not a fan of. The flavor is much of the same. There is a spicy rye and a chocolate malt that drinks like a porter for sure. There is a viscosity and a bitterness about it that isnÂ’t terrible. The mouth feel is robust and brightly carbonated with a bitter roast and spicy rye aftertaste. This isnÂ’t that good at all. Ugh.

Bottle shared with koleminer20. Aroma is rye, spices, slight tart, roasted malt, weird. Appearance is dark brown red, light brown head, would be clear if it wasnÂ’t so dark. Taste is rye, spices, roasted malt, slight cocoa, definitely no saison qualities. Mouthfeel is medium body, light carbonation, roasted malt and rye aftertaste. Overall, just weird. ItÂ’s a porter with rye, it says itÂ’s a saison on the label.

75cl, 2016 vintage - Nov2016, B&Co. - An odd yet workable recipe yielding a tasty mix of autumnal Belgian dubbel (ripe orchard fruit, compote), a musty saison leafiness and some rye spice with hefty body supporting it. Earthy, "organic" and subtle use of earthy EU-pedigree hops. Flourishes of iron, liquorice, quince peel, caramel to keep it interesting. Remarkably demure and mature for a US saison. Could pass off as a new, Fantome-inspired, slightly polished dark saison brewed on Belgian soil.
Six is a great rendition of a rye beer and it delivers in many areas. The aroma just climbs out of the glass and the burst you get from the flavor as it hits the mouth is just as satisfying.

Draft sample at Oedipus International Beer Festival 2016. Amsterdam, The Netherlands. 02.07.2016. Pour it amber color with big white head. Aroma tomato, cherries, woody feel, nice. Taste sweet fruity, vanilla, oak woody feel, some bourbon feel, just a pinch sourish finish. Pretty nice balanced.

On tap at DarbyÂ’s Gastown. Pours a dark copper with a solid tan head. Aroma is spices, fruity, some caramel and tea notes. Taste is sweetÂ’ish, pretty similar to aroma, but with lots of roasted malt notes. Roasted malt, hoppy bitterness aftertaste.

750 ml bottle poured into a snifter. The beer is a dark brown to black with a huge head of beige foam. The beer reminds me a lot of rootbeer. I get a lot of herbal notes and sugary, root nuances. Sweet overall with moderate spice notes coming through. Medium body and medium carbonation.

On tap at the Oedipus International Beer Festival 2016, Amsterdam - day#1 (02-Jul-2016). Reddish brown colour with a medium sized beige coloured head. Aroma of summer fruits and milk chocolate. Medium body and carbonation. Taste of soft fruit - a little cherry and rye. Tart, sweet, with light bitterness. Not bad, but an acquired taste.

On tap @ Oedipus Int. Beer Festival 2016. Nose is red and dark fruits. Body is opalescent brown, head is big, beige, creamy, average lasting, excellent lacing. Aroma is fruity, cherry, milk chocolate, bonbon. Medium sweet, light bitter, light fruity sour. Finish is medium lasting fruity medium bittersweet. Medium body, slick texture, lively carbonation. Quite easy, fruity dessertish beer, nice one.

Sampled from tap at the Oedipus International Beer Festival 2016. Clear, dark brownish red with a massive, creamy, tan head. Sourish, slightly funky and a little fruity aroma of caramel, wild honey, strawberry jam and elderberries. Moderately sour, slightly fruity and a little funky taste of caramel, wild honey, elderberries, red fruits and some cinnamon, followed by a short, slightly tart and quite spicy finish. Medium body, slightly creamy and a little effervescent mouthfeel, average carbonation. Good!
UPDATED: JUN 27, 2016 Delish! Caramely malts and dark spicy saison notes. Complex and heavy but finishes quite light. Very good.
On tap at Liquid Laundry, Shanghai. Pours hazy brown with white head. Aroma of chocolate with some off tasting sources and milk. A very odd beer.

Bottle, thanks hirigalzkar. 
Pours brown with a tan head. 
Sweet and smooth brew. Taste of chocolate, rye, some smoke and a little funk.
Bottle. Strange beer that starts out like a regular saison (grassy, citrusy notes) but ends with some somewhat disturbing cholate notes.

(Upright Six (#6)) Biottle 750 ml at home, served into a big tulip, ABV 6.7%
Brown coloured body, huge and thick, creamy light beige head on top, with very good retention.
Aroma of caramel, rye, red and dark fruits, light wood and yeast.
Taste follows, caramel, red fruits, dark fruits, rye, wood, cork, touches of chocolate even.
Medium body with good carbonation.
Pretty good.

Type: 16-oz. draft
Glass: Joseph James pint glass
From: Naked City Pizza in Paradise (Las Vegas,), Nev.
Price: $7
Purchased: March 25, 2016
Consumed: March 25, 2016
Misc.: Got the last bit of a keg; NOTE: Lost all my notes for this one, going with what I remember and wrote on Untappd

Heard good things about this place, but nothing really intrigued me on the tap list when I got there. Pizza was really good. Originally looked at the draft list, but the bartender told me that the drafts were all kicked. Then went with an Evil Twin Saison, which apparently was out as well. The lady told me that there might be a little bit left of this beer (probably because I ordered a Saison the first time) and she was right. I might have received one of the last two or three cups. NOTE: Read #6 Saison on the board, but this appears to have been a #6 Rye Beer according to Beer Advocate.

Poured an amber, clear color with 1-to-2 fingers of off-white head when I got it. Good amount of lacing on the sides of the glass. Good amount of retention on the way down. (Sight - 4.00)

Smelled red apple, plum, dark fruits, light burnt toffee and earthy grass. (Smell - 4.00)

Taste was just as good, mainly getting red apple, plum, purple grape and light toffee. Some wintry notes - faint molasses and some rye spiciness - coming in as well. (Taste - 4.00)

Medium body. Oily texture. Soft carbonation. Long finish. (Feel - 4.00)

Really wish I would not have deleted my notes, as I enjoyed this one. Would have it again for sure. (Overall - 4.00)

4.00 90 A-

fles van @Benzai, bedankt ! schenk caramel bruin/rood met fijne zachte kaki kraag. aroma van port, rozijn, caramel, zoete mout, donker fruit, bruine suiker. smaken van rogge, caramel, donker fruit, zoet, bruine suiker, licht fruitzuur, rozijnen, bes, pruim, hout, natte bladeren, mout, iets duf, matige body, iets metalige afdronk, zachte co2.
Clear dark reddish brown with a small head. Aroma is heavy on the rye, some grass and caramel notes. Slight hint of dry cocoa on the tongue, dry mouthfeel, medium bodied. Tasty.

Bottled. 35cl sample. The aroma has toffee, licorice, spice, dried fruits. Clear, amber coloured beer with an off-white, medium head. The taste is sweet, has light bitterness, spice/licorice, caramel. Medium bodied. Okay.
Light roast and some hay. Light citrus. Not bad, but enjoyed the five a little more than this one. Pours black with decent head and lacing. Bitter finish. Tap at the Drake.

From 0,75l bottle, Pours clear reddish brown liquid, big frothy tan head, Aroma: light, caramel, chocolate, spicy, red berries, Taste: light to medium sweet, medium bitter, light to medium sour, caramel, chocolate, walnut, spicy,red fruits, black currant, strawberry, hopy, pine, Palate: medium to full body, average carbonation, creamy mouthfeel, long bitter sweet aftertaste, Overall: enjoyed, very nice complex rye saison, lot of chocolate flavors, red fruits, berries, spicy.
Bottle. Pours a dark brown with medium beige head that lasts. The aroma is toasted malt, caramel, wood. Medium mouth sweet malt, caramel, light dry finish, very good.
Tasted @ Borefts Beer Festival 2015. Slightly swampy, rye and a bit bland. Decent body though.
Tap at Borefts Â’15. Pours clear amber red with a small white head. Aroma of ripe dark fruit, caramel, malt and biscuit. Flavour is moderate sweet and bitter. Medium bodied with soft carbonation.

Thx! for sharing. Sampled draft @ De Molen during Borefts 2015. Day 1. Dark amber, mocha head on the sides. Nose is oily herbal hops, thick licorice, cough syrup. Taste is oily pine resin, hops, licorice, some Belgian qualities, nuts, zest, oily resin, dough. Oily leaves, malty body. Not entirely to my taste but interesting & oddly Belgian in an original way.
Keg at borefts. Pours deep amber, nose is burnt toffee, caramel, taste is roasted, burnt, sweet.
Tap at Borefts 2015... Dark copper red... Thin tan lacing.. Soft sweet toffee fruit nose. Soft sweet malts.. Soft toffee fruit soft dry fruit.. Light dry fruits
Tap. Dark brown pour with a nice head. Caramel, chocolate, smoke. Medium body with malt and bitter finish

On tap at upright brewery Portland. Pours out a brown with some rudy highlights topped with a small head. Nose is roast malt caramel and chocolate sweetness along with a little smoke. Taste is more of the sweetness malts and a little ashtray.
Bottle at Stadin Panimobaari, Helsinki. Colour is reddish brown with small white head. Aromas and flavours: Chocolate, some herbs and malts. Simple and way too carbonated.

(Bottle, 0.65 l, at Stadin Panimobaari, 20150821) The beer poured deep brown and hazy. Its head was medium sized and white. Aroma had sweet rye bread, malts and caramel. Palate was medium bodied with medium carbonation. Flavours were malts, caramel, sweetness, molasses, grass and bitterness. Aftertaste was malty and bitter. A malty and fizzy brew.

750ml of old beer. Poured an ugly brown bidy with lots of visible floaties and a fizzy beige head. Aroma of old fruit cake, bad dates and fig, chocolate and dough with a tinge of alcohol. Flavor is lots of cardboard, newspaper, old dates, bad figs, dough, chocolate and some bread crusts. Blah, wase of $$$.

Bottle, pours out a decent darker brown color with a small off white head. Aroma is of candi sugar, dried fruit, soy sauce, and some chocolate and peppery notes. Taste is of some syrup, chocolate, grains, peppery notes, dried fruit, some sweetness.

Bottle @ Camping RateBeers 2015; Nat & Winderig, courtesy of the crew! Pours a hazy amber beer with a small off white head on top. Aroma of rye, red fruits, bread and a faint amount of older hops. Flavor is a bit dull, tarty with yeasty notes, accompanied by some red fruits. Not sure what to think of this, but itÂ’s okay.

At Camping Ratebeers. Brown colour, beige head. Aroma of malts, rye, spicy rye, some caramel, light hoppy. Flavour is medium sweet, malty, rye, spicy, fruity, some caramel, light hoppy finish. Light to medium bodied, firm carbonation. OK-ish.
Chocolade bruine kleur met een volle kraag. Ruikt mout. Smaakt fruitig, zoetig. Beetje kruiden.

Bottled. Pours deep brown with a large off-white head. Aroma of dark fruits, wood, chocolate, bread and mild spicy. Slightly sweet flavor that ends up dry, quite tart and with a hint of bitterness. Medium bodied, oily texture and soft carbonation. A very nice Ale indeed. ðŸŒŸðŸŒŸðŸŒŸðŸŒŸ

750 mL bottle from Tasty Beverage Co., Raleigh, NC. Dark brown pour with a frothy off-white head. Aroma of rye, caramel, light chocolate, hints of smoke, and wood. Somewhat peppery taste with dark fruit flavors, cocoa, and dark roasted rye. Finishes dry and gives the impression of a higher alcohol beer. Nicely done.

Shared bottle, deep dark Amber Brown colour with a tanned head. Nose of sweet caramel, spiced rye, Bread, grains, Some fresh citrus, plums, and sweet malt notice. Soap hops in the hint with a small herbal note. Again dissappointed
Bottle at three men strong tasting. Pours golden/copper with huge off white head. Aroma of malt, sugar, earhty. Taste malts, sugar, dark fruits earthy.
Early summer gettogether in RB Odense. Hazy amber with a s big white head. Bready malt aroma with a fruity touch. Sweet, malty flavour with dried fruit and a touch of creme brulee
Bottle @ Scheffel, Orla and Dolle - 3 men strong ,Odense Tasting. Pours Amber copper with a small frothy head. Mould, cellar, caramel and rotten fruit. NOT fresh!

April 25, 2015. Bottle. 
ight hazy amber with a large off-white head. Aroma is sweet malty with toffee, spicy rye notes, slight almond and grass. Taste is medium sweet caramel, spicy rye, slight grassy bitter with a sweet, spicy and slight earthy finish. Medium bodied, average carbonation.

Bottle. Beermoth, Manchester. Clear, dark amber. Dense, lasting, lacing, light beige head. Nearly as good looking as Morris. Aroma has dried fruit. Caramel. Chewy toffee. Bit of a spicy, grassy hop tang. Taste is light bitter. Some dried fruit sweetness. Palate is soft, massaging, and beautifully light. Finishes light dry, light bitter, with a tad of fruity sweetness. Very drinkable.

750 ml bottle. Courtesy of Timo A. 
Clear amber brown colour with a small frothy light tan head.
Desert wine, dark fruits, fruits, sweetness and toffee in the aroma.
Prunes, dark fruits, mild bitterness, mild chocolate and dark malt in the flavour.
Too fizzy. Messy. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

75 cl bottle @ Timo A.
Pours clear dark copper color with a medium sized head, quite lively. Ashy, toffee and hay on the nose, caramel, maybe some faint rye. Caramel malt flavor, plums, some bread notes, some chocolate on the aftertaste. A bit too strong carbonation, some old hop feel to it also.
4323

Tap at the brewery. 

A: Cloudy mahogany color, creme head. 

N: Toffee, bark, toast, ample amount of nuttiness - almonds and walnuts in particular, peppercorn, and rye bread.

T: Sweeter and maltier side of things; lightly bitter, hint spicy. 

M: Medium body, soft carbonation, no alcohol presence.

O: Solid - the rye is a smart addition here and this is my favorite of the year-rounds.

On tap at Pyrus in Itaewon. Upright 6 on tap at Pyrus. 12,000 won for a smallish pour in a tulip. This Rye Saison pours a deep black with a thick creamy beige head. Served cold do a mild spicy nose. The taste is tangy tart earthy spicy rye - very smooth.
Tap at the brewery. Dark Amber colour, aroma is black treacle and spice. Taste is great, rye, grainy, little bit of treacle again, molasses.
On tap. Pours brown with red hues. Aroma is very estery, peppery, spices, raisin. Taste is med bodied, med carbonation, very Belgian estery. Overall good but nothing impressive.

Nice beer. Tap at alibi. Pours brown limited head lots lacing. Nose is quiet. Flavours are prunes, some light chocolate, maybe some lemon. Taste light sweet cry light bitter and touch sour but not much. Light body with medium carbonation.
Cola brown pour. Aroma is malty madness. Flavours more down the amber ale territory (not a fave style of mine). Rye is quite minimal sadly. Overall, nice but not much farmhouse character.

Very carbonated upon opening. Not my cup of teaÂ…. Muddy and murky dark brown with 3-4 fingers of foamy head. Does not quickly fade. Nose smells like a homebrew, muddled and rustic malt notes with some dark fruit and plum. Rye malt is really showing big in here with some oxidized and bready notes. Medium light bodied with an earthy finish.
Bottled, thanks hackobock!  Hazy amber, rich head. Marzipan and sugar up front. Sweet with medium body and rounded mouthfeel. Bready with notes of pepper and sugar. Low bitterness.

4oz draft at GBD. Poured a thin, semi-translucent, but still dark, almost black, perhaps like a mahogany color. Aroma was light rye, some light dark cherries, coffee notes. Some funky notes, fruity character comes through a bit. Pretty refreshing and easy to drink.
Draft - Light roast and chocolate malts. Deep jet brown with a beige head. Light roast me some chocolate notes. Some Belgian yeasty fruit notes and some soy like tartness.

Pours hazy deep amber with three fat fingers of pillowy beige head, excellent retention and lacing. (4/5) Nose is caramel malt, black pepper, dark chocolate, wood, stone fruit, horseblanket. (7/10) Taste is moderate sweet, moderate bitter, mild tart. (7/10) Medium bodied, moderate carbonation, clean finish. (4/5)

Well, itÂ’s different - and different is always good. IÂ’ve literally never had - or even heard of - a rye saison before. I can see the rye and saison characters, but the interesting thing is, together they almost come across as a dubbel. ItÂ’s one heck of an interesting beer: sweet, deep and complex, with just a little sour funk. Hellishly difficult to pour, though! (15/20)

Pours a deep amber color with a dark fruit aroma. Taste of rye, caramel, and a small cherry flavor. The rye taste overwhelmed this beer which made it dry and crisp. Minimal aftertaste and sweetness throughout.

[2/26/15] Draught at Upright Brewing in Portland. Nice deep amber-brown, a bit shiny, with a tan head. Aroma of fruits, spiciness, malt, a bit of licorice and spicy rye. Sweetish flavor, fruity, malty, with caramel, spice, licorice and an alcoholic note. Medium-bodied.
Caramel and toasted malts, rye, bread, barley, very wholesome beer. Nice finish. Dry, medium carbonation, some alcohol detection. Not bad.

Bottle. Opaque purplish brown pour. Very nice beer. Definitely get the rye but some cherry and other fruits in it as well. Smooth, not too boozy. Just a nice beer. Would love to have it again if I could find it.

750 ml bottle at home. Pours a darkrreddish brown color with a medium plus sized off white head. The aroma and flavor have dark fruits, cherry, chocolate, spicy rye, caramel, yeast, some acidity and tartness to go with the funk.

Dusty, fruity aroma with light sourness. Foggy tea color, filmy head, small white sediment. Wine bottle, good label. Golden raisins, peaty malt, pointed bitterness, hops hit you in the back of the high palate. Lightish body. Warming. Peppery aftertaste. Thanks to someone at Baby Proof for sharing.
(Tap) I like this one. It has some spiciness but is still quite refreshing.

Pours a deep almost ruby amber with a smaller tab head that laced. Aroma of tart cherries, spicy rye notes and hints of dark chocolate. Flavor of toasted malt, light roast, tart cherries and rye bread.

Bottle. Pours a dark brown color with a very large light brown head on there. Nose has some roasting to it as well as caramel, and just a bit of rye spice coming through. Taste is dry up front with a bit of coffee and toastiness, then has just a hint of caramel sweetness in the finish. Interesting and complex...
Draft at the Hop Grenade. Earthy hop nose, dark Amber poir with a thick tan head (killed the keg). Malty, earthy slightly spicy saison. Nice.

750ml bottle in a tulip. Pours hazy brown with a lacy, beige head. Aroma of some spiciness, some caramel and toffee malts, light floral hops, and some hints of fruity notes. Flavor the same. Average texture. A decent beer.
"Dry and spicy, and chewy and malty all at the same time. Interesting brew to say the least. Pepper, hops, sweet English brown malt, dark fruits... Quite the combo."

How: Bottle.
Where: Shared during RBESG 14.
Appearance: Hazy brown colour, some yeast particles, tan head.
Aroma: Fruit, caramel, malt.
Body: Medium body and carbonation.
Flavour: Caramel, fruit, raisin, a bit acidic.

Marron/rouge sombre avec un tÃªte moyen beige. LÂ’arÃ´me du malt avec un peu dÂ’houblon floral. Le goÃ»t est dominÃ© par le malt non-sucrÃ©. Puis il y a un peu dÂ’houblon du seigle et une finition sec. Pas vraiment un saison mais trÃ¨s bonne!

Pours a dark brown, with ample tan head. Aroma of dark malts and rye. Taste of cherry, malt and dark fruits. The taste is slightly bitter and complex. Not particularly smooth, this one is not my cup of tea.

Bottle bought @ bierkompass.de. Pours murky goldenish brown with a huge brownish beige head that slowly dissipates while leaving some thick lacing and trace on the glass while dissipating. Smell is malty and phenolic with rye bread, rye flour, baked pears, dried pineapple, hay, black pepper corns, leather and lemon zest. Taste is slightly sweet, bitter, malty and slightly phenolic with rye bread, mango, dried pineapple, baked pears, hay, dry soil, black pepper corns and orange zest. Mouthfeel is soft, round, very tiny tart and medium bodied. Finish is bitter, malty and phenolic with rye bread, baked pears, dried tropical fruits, black pepper corns, hay, dry soil and orange zest. A bad idea to begin with but executed in a pretty good way.
Dark red-brown, sweet, earthy and a hint of caramel and toast. Dryish, not bad. The rye shows mostly in the finish. Not my ideal type of beer.

Bottle share thanks to Kenny. Murky orange caramel with a light cream head. Aroma is sweet caramel, orange, some age. Flavour is sweet berry, orange, caramel malts toffee. Palate is semi sweet, moderate carbonation. Light liquorice. Some age but pretty tasty.

8th August 2014RBESG pt 5. Brew By Numbers. Bottle share. Very hazy amber beer, small pale cream colour head. Palate is airy and dry. Mild fine carbonation. Fair bit of crystal malt like caramel. Little toffee as well. Light dried fruits and light dry malt cream. Heavy on the caramel and lacks refinement but not terrible by any means.

Bottle shared during RBESG - thanks to Kenny. Pours golden-amber, foamy off-white head. The nose has crunchy bread, toffee, caramel. Medium sweet flavor with toasty bread, dried caramel, some old orange. Medium bodied with fine carbonation. Sweet finish with more toffee, aged malts, read. Tasty.
Bottle at RBESG14. Hazy dark amber beige head. Sticky sweet aroma. Some decent hop on the finish. Ok but a tad sweet for me.

Holy bubbles, Batman! Bottle, a few weeks old. Pours reddish/caramel brown with mountains of tan head. Super carbonated. Aroma is caramel, brown sugar, dish soap. Light and crisp body, plenty of dark fruits (fig stands out, some raisin) and malt come through. This was a fizzy one for sure. Enjoyed it.

Aroma is sweet with slight rye spice malt. Cherry aroma is faint. Appears dark amber with a average off white head. Taste is slightly Belgian yeast sweet malt, spicy malt, back end bitter with fruit, crisp pepper and cherry skin. I sound like an asshole. ItÂ’s good but not my taste.

Taster on tap at iTAP-CWE in STL during RBSG. Mildly hazy red brown color. Thin off-white khaki head. Leaves good thicker lace. Interesting chewy rye malt profile. Soft, smooth, lighter carbonation. Medium to bigger body. Light slick. Some chocolate aromas, hint of fruit. Moderate sweet taste, light spicy, some herbal notes. Cool interesting unusual beer. Great way to do a rye beer. Nice one to try.
Bottle courtesy of toffsbury. Cloudy, with a tan head. Spicy yeasty aroma. Very dry taste, light spiciness, slight caramel notes, with a dry finish. I like this.

Appearance: this beer pours with a huge and very dense tan head, the beer is a hazy brown color, head had excellent retention and lacing

Aroma: strong caramel, some zest, bread, raisin, floral, very complex and aromatic

Taste: sweet, coffee, chocolate, some hints of pine, plum, hints of moderately roasted grain

Palate: heavy body, soft carbonation, leaves a faint bitter aftertaste

Overall: another very impressive beer from upright brewing, this beer is delicious, aromatic, complex, and unique

With Zach and Brandon on the patio, pours a dark mahogany brown color with a medium to large head. Nose is grainy and grassy. Taste is caramel, malt and toffee. Light taste and flavor. Finishes on the same tasting notes with a sweet toffee like ending. Plain and generic. Quaff Score 6 / 10
Pours a muddy brown with a tan head and aroma of malt, caramel, and rye. Taste is of sweet malt notes, rye, caramel, fruits, and spices with a dry, bitter finish

750 ml bottle poured a clear reddish brown with a small lasting tan head. Aromas of rye, caramel, cocoa and light pepper. Palate was light to medium bodied and crisp with a dry finish. Flavors of caramel, rye, earthiness and light spice with a crisp dry lingering rye finish.

Slightly clear dark amber under a thin tight foamy light tan head. The nose has some caramalt and toasted biscuit but thereÂ’s also this rye bread dough tone with a touch of honey and earthy toffee. Smooth flavor with some sweet earthy toffee, some light honey, rye, and toasted biscuit malt with some Belgian fruity yeast esters. Very complex and lovely.

Cask at Alibi Room, VancouverCloudy brown color with large frothy head. The aroma is mildly spicy, nutmeg. Smooth and soft mouthfeel, some caramel flavor, highly drinkable, fresh, a bit spicy and nutty, very lightly soapy.I donÂ’t favour spicy beers, but itÂ’s quite tasty.

hazy amber, thin cream ring, good lacing. Heavy caramel front, light burnt sugar, pear, and metallicity. Juicy front palate is lightly burnt sugar, red delicious, tons of grain across mid, estery in bubblegum with lightly burnt end, sticky and full, decent dryness takes over in the finish.
750 ml. bottle. Pours a dark reddish brown with a huge tan head. Aroma of malt, fruit, and yeast. Taste is rye, yeast, malt, fruit, floral, and spice. Very drinkable.

Pours quite dark with a bit of a crimson hue. The aroma has mushy doughiness, granola, cream and light rye. It has a medium smooth body with quite a bit of smooth carbonation. The taste starts off with toffee / caramel, earthy belgian yeastiness, rye spice, dry doughiness and some nutty toastiness. The finish has lots of dough and is very malty. NIce, but not what expected.

750 ml bottle, Deep brown color, massive over carbonation, had to be poured real slow. Nose shows fruity Belgian yeast with rye bread and earthy malts. 
After the carbonation there is no problems and the flavor is rather nice. Rye malts, earthy tones of dried leaves and subtle Belgian yeast. Light body with a dry texture. 
Overall this is nicely crafted and falls just short of being spectacular. The over carbonation gave me a ton of bad burps.

Bottle. Lots and lots of slightly tanned foam, dark muddy brown almost quad like. Aroma lemon, mild hops, and dusty grains. Taste starts off slight sweet, gets a little yeasty and lemon like towards the middle finishes semi bitter with a lemon, herb/grains like aftertaste that lingers on the back of your tongue. Really nice stuff, a bit richer than most of the saisons iÂ’ve had but really nice nonetheless.

Bottle: Dark brown in color, sort of a flat brown. Huge pile of fluffy tan head that takes a lengthy time to subside. Nose is spicy and lightly floral. Rye is evident, also in the taste. Slightly fruity and sweet before turning dry, husky, and earthy. Light florals linger. Good use of rye and the saison yeast.
Bottle. Pours a dark amber color with off white head. Caramel, spicy, yeasty, malty aromas. Malty, caramel, dark fruit flavors. A bit cardboardy. Nothing special.

Draft. Pours a medium, weÂ’ll retained light beige head with attractive lacing, over a clear brown (SRM 23) body.....nose is rye, cocoa, chocolate, mild hop spice....taste is rye, cocoa, chocolate, mild hop spice and bitterness on the finish......mouth feel light of medium, slight alcohol warmth, clean acid finish. This is a pleasant, quite complex beer that is nicely balanced. BJCP 7/3/14/4/7

Draft at Upright a few weeks ago - from notes. How have I never had this? Dark, red-brown pour with minimal head. Aroma: caramel; stone fruits (think: Belgian strong meets Scotch ale). Some ash. April 28th, 2012 - UprightÂ’s Brewing Six is a beer that I purchased on a lark, and those tend to be very risky business indeed. Whole Foods has a tendency to groom their beer shelves in a way where a strategic part or a a prominent plateau can pull the shopperÂ’s eye to a privileged beer. How Whole Foods impairs my judgment, I cannot say. I suspect the delicious pizza-by-the-slice is drugged. Whatever the business method chosen, I grabbed a bottle of Upright BrewingÂ’s Six knowing nothing about the brewery, its location, or even what the Six stood for. Supposedly itÂ’s the sixth in a series of venerable beers, but for all I know, it could be the number of bottles they executed to sell. That certainly canÂ’t be true, however, because this is an excellent beer and a tasty companion to a weekend evening. It pours cloudy and chalky, producing a blooming aroma that is intense with rye, rye bread, and a bitter bite that keeps my nose at a safe distance. This doesnÂ’t mean IÂ’m retreating from the beer, but IÂ’m admiring it from afar, like that creepy guy on the back of the bus who seems to be taking in his environment with a little too much intensity. A cornucopia of grains defines the flavor. This is an unwelcome place for sugars. The Six instead focuses on blending malts and the rolled rye to deliver a liquid meal: molasses and bread, pumpernickel too, and a yeasty touch that reminds me of the lighter grains of flavor that always seem to appear in saisons. And harkening back to joyous rides in carts around pumpkin patches or circuses, there is the intense grassiness of golden, bundled hay, all in a delicious drinkable form.

On tap. Hazy brown with a thick tan head. Scent is caramel, yeast, rye and fruity. Taste is rye, caramel, citrus, and grass.

Tap. Pours hazy dark ruby brown with a small beige head and nice lacing. Aroma is like rye bread, cocoa, molasses, sorghum. Flavor is the same, medium sweet with minimal bitterness and some rye spiciness. Light bodied. Very interesting and different beer. I enjoyed this one.

Bottle shared with Linh, Ken, Nicca, Daddy & Mom Vuong. Pours a deep, murky brown body with nice lacing. Aroma is bready, spice, rye, and sweet malts. Mouthfeel is medium with notes of sweet raisin bread, dark fruit, sweet malt, spice, light wood and malts.

Shared bomber from Binnys with Sherm1016...pours a rich brown with white head and lacing...interesting mix of scents and flavors that my taste buds canÂ’t sort out except to call Â’em yummy!  Definite hoppy bite at the end...very tasty...

750ml bottle, shared by dwm1034. Thanks!  Pours a deep, dark amber-brown color with a big tan head.  Aroma is malty, bready, maybe a little orange citrus.  Medium on the palate with soft carbonation.  Flavor is sweet, malty, caramel, fruity, tart cherry, some pineapple hops, with a light fruity finish.  Surprised at how much my take agrees with the description.  Very tasty.

On draft at THE LOCAL beer bar in Eureka, CA,  Pours a rich dark brown with a big and creamy light tan head that had great retention and left excellent lacing rings.  The nose is of dark roasted malt and dark ripe fruit.  Medium plus in body. Good rich mouthfeel. The flavor is very rich with some chocolate, ripe fruit and some wood. Finish is funky, and quite dry A really tasty and enjoyable brew.

Bottle at home with my dad. Pour is deep brown with a huge, off-white head and great lacing. This one is way over-carbonated; the foam just continues to grow and is starting to come out of my glass. Rye, bread, citrusy hops, floral, and soapy aroma. Taste is toffee, light roast, dark cherries, somewhat belgian yeasty, citrus, and soapy hops with a light bitter finish. Medium mouthfeel with high carbonation.  Pretty tasty stuff.

750ml bottle pours a hazy, light brown with some thin, white head.  Nose is fairly neutral, some bread, some yeast, light nuts.  Flavor is similar, lightly sweet, lightly nutty, some bread, a little doughy.  Medium bodied, dry finish.  A session beer, no question, but I was hoping for a bit more complexity.
Sweet caramel and rye nose with a touch of raisin. Taste is light to moderately sweet, lots of dark fruit, light cola, light chocolate and eye bread. Decent.

Bottle courtesy of BrainLair.  Pours a thick brown pour with a slight orange tint.  Thin tan head.  Nutty toasted grain on the nose.  Flavor is dry and bitter.  Peppery with faint notes of chocolate and tropical fruit.  Lightly tart hoppy finish.

750mL thanks to EricE. Pours a full hazed deep brune with sheen, dense, yellowish foam. Thick, sheety lacing. Nose is a bit vegetal, tomato soup, celery stalk. Taste is heavy malt cereal, moving to lemon tea and finishing very whole wheat crackery. Palate is still a bit vegetal, mildly tart, freezer burn flavors. Hmm. As it warms, some chocolate comes through with mild banana esters. Improving to near dunkelweizen. Still odd. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Dark red brown body, healthy sized off-white head, a smattering of lacing.  Nose is bold, with characteristic of earthy/spicy notes from the rye, some caramel and pale malts come through.  A little crackery.  Flavor presents a similar profile deep, earthy impression with a little fruit and cocoa.  Medium bodied.  Noticeable, but not overwhelming bitterness.  A little prickly.
Dark coppery brown with a foamy tan head. Tart, a bit yeasty, full. Dark fruit (cherry, raisin) with a hint of roasted malt and spice.

Poured into a tulip.

5.0 A: Lightly hazed deep mahogany color. Two fingers of creamy/pillowy beige head. Retention is very good and a thick, juicy ring of lacing is left.

4.0 S: Big caramel component to start things off. Spicy earthy rye, earthy hops, and pepper follow. Toasty with berry, orange, and apple notes. A touch of cocoa powder.

3.5 T: Starts off with caramel, cocoa powder, and plenty of earthy hoppiness. Spicy earthy rye follows with toasty malts and pepper from the yeast. Orange and apple fruitiness. The berries donÂ’t manifest in the taste. Moderate bitterness. Good flavors, but itÂ’s a little dry for my tastes and the overall flavor intensity is on the lower end.

3.5 M: Lighter medium body. A bit too much carbonation. The carbonation is aggressive without being very spritzy. Otherwise, this has a good creaminess.

3.5 D: ItÂ’s hard to pick one between Five and Six as which one I like better. They are both tasty, but they are fully different. This has some good flavors, but is missing something in the taste. Worth a try, but probably not another buy.

750 ml bottle into tulip glass, no bottle dating.  Pours very hazy dark reddish brown color with a nice 2-3 finger fluffy khaki head with fantastic retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lasts.  Nice thick foamy lacing clings to the glass.  Aromas of caramel, mango, cherry, biscuit, toffee, molasses, orange zest, pineapple, toast, and rye spiciness.  Very nice and unique aromas with good balance, complexity, and strength.  Taste of caramel, toast, molasses, biscuit, pepper, pineapple, chocolate, clove, earth, cherry, citrus, and rye spiciness.  Light spicy bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of caramel, molasses, cherry, chocolate, pepper, earth, toast, and rye spiciness on the finish for a bit.  Great balance of flavors with nice complexity; fairly dry on the finish.  High carbonation and medium body; with a fairly crisp, slick, and lightly prickly mouthfeel that is very nice.  Alcohol is well hidden with only a slight warming noticed after the finish.  Overall this is an excellent rye saison!  Great flavor complexity and balance; and very smooth a crisp to sip on.  A very unique and enjoyable offering.  Very well done.

Deep mahogany with quickly fading head.  Aroma is a faint burst of pepper and white sage falling over a backdrop of malty chocolate.  Body is on the lighter side but not watery.  Flavors of caramel, fig, and a hit of citrus in the finish.  Slight lingering bitterness with a bit of solventy ester in the finish, reminds me of lime rind and especially the pith.  Good not great.
On tap at Beer Authority. Pours a muddy brown with two fingers tannish head. Smell is funky barnyard. Taste is crisp, rye, funk, and hay. Good saison.

750 mL bottle shared with ahuds58. Pours a rich chestnut hue with smallish bubbly head. Lovely, if subtle, nose with notes of sourdough bread, rye, cherry and plum, light tobacco, coffee, and earthy guava. Flavor starts fruity with apricot, mango, and rich cherry, along with earthy hops and nice dark spiciness. Maybe a bit overcarbonated, but refreshing and lovely overall.

Bottle, 07/05/2012.  Pours a muddy brown, dense beige head, effervescent bubbles.  Aroma of rye bread; spicy, nutty chocolate, caramel and light, slightly tart fruitiness.  Taste is mostly similar: rye grain upfront with nutty caramel, pepper, touch of red fruity tartness, and a long, dry, bitter rye finish.  Full, round palate.  DidnÂ’t get any of the more funky elements some are reporting, this may be a fresher bottle?  Anyways, not too bad.

Bottle - Pours murky mahogany with a huge foamy off white head. Nose is lightly spicy white pepper, light tropical fruit, and a real light breadiness. Nice and dry. Taste brings some dark rye bread in, with a bit of bitter dark chocolate, light grassy, herbal hopping, and a bit of fruity sweetness. Light and well-carbonated. Good stuff.

Pour at ScottÂ’s saison tasting, pour out of bottle is dark reddish brown with off white head, aroma has notes of mineral water, nice rye spice, grain, caramel, toffee, some biscuit and slight dark fruits with a hint of lactic, interesting for sure.  Taste is rye, grain, biscuit and toffee, some dark fruit, lactic, hints of earth and a slight mineral water, finishing fairly dry and slightly bitter.
Nice saison thats a bit heavy handed on the rye.  Taste is very strong rye with nice peppery woody notes from the saison.  Dry smooth finish.

UPDATED: JUN 21, 2012 On tap at Gourmet Haus. Rich aroma of wet dark grain. Subtle spicy roast. Mahogany with creamy taupe head. Nice lacing down glass. Flavor is spicy and roast chocolate. Full bitter finish. Dryish throughout with astringent finish. Well carbonated and chewy yeast/rye medium-full mouthfeel. Roast persists on the late palate.

Bottle. Courtesy of resenaren. Pours a hazy amber color with a small off-white head. Has a slightly roasted malty spicy yeasty aroma. Slightly roasted malty spicy yeasty flavor with hints of caramel. Has a slightly roasted malty spicy yeasty caramel finish.

750 bottle. It pours a dark orange/ruby color with a nice off white head. The aroma has lots of rye malt with a touch of caramel and some spicy hops. The flavor is rather savory with some toast and dense, grainy rye malt. Theres a bit of cherry, bread and lots of peppery hops toward the finish. Pretty dry and full bodied. This reminds me of one of those freshly baked multi grain breads. Pretty nice, especially paired with the right meal.

On tap @ Urban Family. Pours a watery caramel brown. Aroma is sweet malts and just a hint of hops. Taste is rich and complex: oatmeal, toffee, dark chocolate, tangy pineapple hops, lightly roasted coffee.  The rye shows itself on the back in the dry and hoppy finish.  I canÂ’t remember this much flavor from such a thin beer. I was expecting a Saison, so this was a surprising treat.
750 ml bottle. Pours a very dark brown with full head. Aromas of malt, raisins and spice. Definite sharp woody flvor right up front, followed by sour dark fruit and vinous notes. Interesting.

Muddy chocolate with fair beige head / Somewhat sour nose of orchard fruit, caramel, chocolate, and oak / Medium body, dry with only a hint of sweetness, somewhat tart and astringent, hoppy, with bitter finish / Flavors of rotten apple, caramel, chocolate, oak, and rye spice / Close to a sour ale, enjoyable but a little excessively bitter.

Good beer. Has a unique taste. Dark amber pour with a gray head. Tropical fruit smell. Tastes good. Only downside is a weird aftertaste. It's a particular element. Had in bottle.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
This is a complex beer. Some sweetness in the aroma. Orange-brown. A bit fruity for a rye beer. Some strange grainiess from the rye. Good but odd.

Bottle. Pours a hazy caramel brown with a gray head that dissipates slowly to the edges. Aroma has a good amount amount of dark fruits with an earthy chocolate note and a hint of spice. Flavor starts with some sweet dark grains that is joined by a dark fruit note that is backed by spice and an earthy yeast note.

Sampled at an esbls tasting.  Mid brown and opaque.  A nice creamy beige head.  Nice rye and fruit flavors.  Big malt and grain flavors with an almost balancing hop back ground.  Cherries and bark.  Tasty and smooth.

Bottle; Pour is murky dark brown / amber with a fine bubbled khaki head that retains fairly well in this glass; there is some average lacing present. The nose is a bit on the peppery side, with some caramel and mild belgian notes present. The flavor profile I find to be quite nice overall;  it has a fairly smooth mouthfeel, a light bitterness near the finish;  there are some light fruits here, the rye elements are certainly present, more pepper comes through, with some sweetness from the caramel malts. I enjoyed this one quite a bit -

Bottle. Dark ruby red/brown with tan head. Nose/taste of grapes, sweet malt, raisins, dark fruits and spicy rye. Taste is initial sweet and vinous grape that morphs into spicy rye. Medium body. Mild acidity.

750mL @ Engine House #9. I hope for the breweryÂ’s sake, this bottle had gone bad. I love a good rye beer; this was not one. Poured hazy amber. Very thin, almost no head. Aroma of dirty tap lines (from a bottle?) and musty, wet cardboard. No hop aroma whatsoever. Flavor, again, tasted like a beer that had gone bad (from light?, dirty lines?) No lacing, no mouth feel. Hint of rye sourness, but not nearly enough to make up for the overwhelmingly strong "off" flavors. CouldnÂ’t finish a single pint glass. Simply awful. After reading some reviews, I get the feeling that there wasnÂ’t a lot of consistency from batch to batch (assuming there were several batches).

22 oz. stolen from Carl. Oooh, rye is quickly becoming my favorite grain. Kind of a rusty red color thatÂ’s all sorts of cloudy. Rye makes it a nice smooth palate and offers up some subtle complexities in the malt profile. Hint of Belgian yeasts which seem to have tinned a bit.

On tap at the brewery. Pours a dark brown color with a mediumw white head. A sweet nose of grains and light burnt caramel. The flavor is a basic sweet grain forward brew with some light spicy rye and a bit of floral hops, very clean. Dry.

BottleÂ… Pours cloudy with a mahogany hue and a huge, frothy, off-white head. Great retention. The bouquet furnishes notes of spicy grain, caramel and both black and white pepper. Medium-bodied and mildly astringent with airy carbonation. The flavor delivers spicy grains, moderate acidity and light caramel sweetness. Tangy, spicy, dry finish. Bottle courtesy of landhoney!

Tap at MonkÂ’s Kettle, SF. It pours cloudy dark brown, with a massive cream head. The nose is farmyard, orange citrus fruit, salted caramel, pine and rye bread. The taste is rye bread, farmyard, orange citrus, dark fruit (raisin, currant, cherry and plum), hay, caramel and a touch of chocolate, with a long dry finish. Medium body and soft carbonation. An interesting brew indeed.

Thanks to my personal mule, lurpy1, for bringing this treat back from Sacramento. IÂ’m almost to the bottom of my stash. When are you going back? 750 ML bottle shared with my wife. 

Pours dark red with a ruby glint around the edges & persistent head, even with a gentle hand. Smell is wild: rye, spices, passing hops, even a shot of alcohol. Faint fruit, too. Lovely. 

Upright Six is a beer you could assign random descriptors & probably be right. The spices & the yeast vie for attention when the brew hits the tongue; an almost saisonesque undercurrent merges with an understated rye spiciness. Peppery. Fruit is almost a tart blackberry or underripe blueberry; odd. Slight must right at the end. Grainy, too. Aggressively carbonated. Weirdly appealing & disappears like thereÂ’s a hole in the side of the glass. 

Huge complexity on this one that doesnÂ’t quite mesh together; oddly less than the sum of its parts. Lots of goodness in here, though. Good beer.

Pours a deep, dark, reddish brown, with a lingering mid-size head. Powerful aroma -- slightly tart cherry cordials over caramel and bitter chocolate, with some roasted grains and a bit of wood. Really nice on the nose. Flavor is a bit weak at first. Starts with the same notes you find in the aroma, then shows a burst of pine-resin hops, then fades into toasted grains. It has a thick mouthfeel, but it finishes bone dry and fairly bitter. This would be a great complement to food -- IÂ’m thinking a marinated flank steak or tri-tip. As it is, though, I wish the flavor had as much punch as the aroma.
Draft.  Pours a mostly clear deep amber.  Smell is fig, other ripe fruits and caramel.  Taste is sweet from the caramel with a spiceiness and more ripe fruit.  Nice.

750mL bottle, no date from Best Damn Beer Shop, $10.99.  Clear auburn brown with a one finger beige head, fading to a thick ring and sparse film before long.  Tangy fruity red wine grape/cherry up front in the nose with some peppery yeast and rye, some roast and chocolate notes in the backend, but still pretty apparent.  Tinge of caramel is in there as well, but only as it warmed.  Flavor follows suit--quite fruity with plenty of rye and a fair amount of complementing chocolate malt and roast.  Sweetness is quite restrained--sourness peaked at a 2 1/2, finish is dry. Bitterness peaked at a 3, earthy.  Low carbonation with a medium body.  DoesnÂ’t have the typical white pepper and fruit notes of a more traditional saison, but very tasty nonetheless--I liked it quite a bit more as I worked my way through the bottle. Rate #100!
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: Dark brown with a lasting off white head. The aroma has some spicy, toasty caramel, fruity yeast esters with some stone fruit, and earthy chocolate. There is some mild chocolate in the flavor as well as spice and fruity yeast. Medium bodied with a sweet finish.

RBAG - Bottle, again thanks to Cydd. Pours murky tawny/green with a pinkish flash to it. 1-finger off-white head, soft lacing. Nose is tart with smoky rye, tart rhubarb, cassis; Flavours of tart rye, funky bleu cheese, some rhubarby fruit. Kinda tastes like a hibiscus Saison, what with the rhubarb and everything. Not sure IÂ’m a huge fan of this, just kinda seems all over the place to me...

RBAG. From green 750ml. Dark brown and hazy. Good frothy tan cap. Nose caramelly, sweetish, bit of chocolate. Tart up front in the mouth, chocolate malts, caramel. Light bitterness and some yeasty aftertastes ans some sourness. Tingly carbonation. Medium body. Nice mix of sweet and sour elements.

Muted aromas of malt, rye, blackp epper. Woody hop-tingle in the mouth,  roast malt, distant molasses--served up dry. good balance of carbonation and weight. Very well done, crisp, clean, subdued but still interesting hints,

750 ml bottle. Lots of caramel in the nose, I did not expect that with the rye in the beer. The rye is very noticeable in the flavor, as well as a slight tartness, caramel, citrus. An interesting beer.

Surprisingly delicious beer. DoesnÂ’t smack you in the face with flavor or intensity, but after a few sips it seems to get deeper and more complex in a curiously subtle way. Notes of multigrain bread, yeast esters, toffee, chocolate and earthy-herbal hops weave in and out of one another seamlessly. ItÂ’s the perfect blend of flavors and itÂ’s perfectly balanced. I drank the entire bottle myself and never got bored with it. In fact, it just made me want more.

750 ml bottle. Big rye nose, acid, slightly acetic, light esters, fruit. Dark brown with lace. Sour flavor with rye, caramel, nuts, vinegar. The clean, sour edge is nice, but maybe not enough malt behind it. Hoppy, bitter finish. Huge rye flavor is interesting.

750ml bottle poured amber in color with a 2 finger off-white head that retained well but left little lacing behind.  Aroma is light chocolate with some fruit and wood.  Taste is light fruity and malty sweet notes with a mild hoppy bitterness with traces of woodiness.  A decent beer with a medium body and soft carbonation but I was expecting much more from this one.

Tap at Upright - an interesting brew, to be sure - hazy amber - nose is moderately acidic, with spicy rye, yeast, cloves, spices - flavor is the same - a little acidic up front, followed by rich toasty maltiness, floral hops, light clove, spicy phenols - crisp, gingerbread finish - lingering acidity - interesting.

bottle... dark mahogany that almost looks black, cool color, light tan head, a two finger cap sticks around for several minutes, not much lacing... interesting aroma, caramel, light cherries, wood, a bit spicy... taste is all over the place, wood is harsh, peppery, watery, oats, grainy bland finish... not a winner

Bottle: &nbsp Deep burnt caramel, brownish of sorts, large light beige head, nice lacing. &nbsp Bright barnish 

nose, definite rye. &nbsp Rich maltiness on the tongue, rye, and a bit of straw/hay. &nbsp Feels a bit spritzy and 

bubbley. &nbsp Strong rye from start to finish. &nbsp Mild sweetness, lingering barnishness. &nbsp Body and mouthfeel 

are moderate, albiet very effervescent. &nbsp Smidgen of a chocolate like malt on the finish. &nbsp Overall its fairly 

tasty, heavy on the rye, malty, spritzy, with a rustic barnish like finish. &nbsp Maybe could use a little more 

sweetness, but otherwise enjoyable.

Pours a cloudy brown with thick tan tinged head that sticks. Aroma is pepper and cherry. Flavor is a mix of herbs, sour cherry bread and caramel. Definitely a sour note to the beer. Body is light with a lot of carbonation.
Are you kidding me? This beer is so beautiful! Wood, cherry, sour, musty. A lot of sour. Thin body. DonÂ’t pass this one up.

750ml from Northwest Liquid Gold. Quite different from the other Upright brews IÂ’ve had so far, which tend to be on the more dry side of the saison world. This one was a fairly dark orange pour, with a nose of tart balsamic, passion fruit, and Beaujolais. Nicely prickly body with a dry finish, the taste was quite enigmatic compared with the aroma, and was comprised of dark chocolate, sour bread yeast, lots of herbs, and a bit of sangria. Truly quirky, and very, very enjoyable.

Bottle @ home. Dark brown appearance with a big, light brown head. Slightly tart, dark fruity, light barnyard, belgian yeasty aroma. Tart, dark cherry, dark fruity, rye, belgian yeasty, slightly woody flavor with a dry, tart finish. Earthy, dark fruity aftertaste.

750 ml bottle.  Picked this up on a whim at Texas Liquor in Carlsbad.   The commercial description above is actually spot on.   Surprisingly, itÂ’s both tart and a little spicy.  It works, though.  Palate is very nice:  Smooth and a little creamy.  Finishes pretty dry and tart.

On Draft at P town brewpub 2009. Aroma: Refreshing hop
Flavor: Roasty chocolate from start to finish with some light/medium 
citrus on the mid-palate.
750ml bottle. Poured a brown color with a small sized off white head. Musty...pile of raked leaves. Earthy with lighter caramel and chocolate.

The pour is a dark brown color with a big fizzy tan head.  I can definitely smell the funky yeast here but it collides with toasted grain, clove, and even some chocolate, in an interesting aroma.  This isnÂ’t really tart but there is a spritzy sourness to it with relatively high carbonation, which I think masks some of the flavors.  Behind that though is funky yeast, toasted grain, caramel, rye, and apple.  Comes across as a little cracker like.  It certainly opens up as it warms.  This is by far my least favorite of the Upright beers IÂ’ve tried so far yet thereÂ’s a lot of interesting things going on so it was still quite a bit of fun to try.

Thanks to mdfb79 for sharing this the other night. Served in a SAVOR snifter.

Pours a nice copper color with a bit of a reddish hue. Good off-white head and some nice spotty lacing on the way down.

The nose brings forward a really strong rye presence. A bit of that rye sourness comes through along with an earthy component. Flavor focuses too much on the rye and lets the other components of the beer get away. Medium body with good carbonation and a dry, slightly-tangy finish.

Pretty good, but too much focus on the rye and not enough on the yeast.
Bottle shared by Seth at the District.  Light brown pour with a beige head.  Malty nose.  I found the flavor to be very bland and unexciting with heavy generic malt notes.

750ml bottle from city beer strore in San Fran.  Aroma is musty, burnt sugar, and slight sour.  Taste is tart, toast, sour, chocolate, and pepper.  Creamy medium texture.  Sweaty acidic finish.  Strange, but ineresting.

750ml bottle from K&L.  Shared at a party, where one of the beer philistinians there had the AUDACITY to call it "skunked."  Puh-leeze.  DonÂ’t you know what a Belgium is?  Ok, enough pretending to be an idiot.  This brewski is a good one.  Clear dark amber-brown in color with a large light beige head that lasts.  The aroma is interesting, with chocolate, spices, dark fruits, wood, and a Belgian note.  The flavor is surprisingly chocolatey with some caramel, spicy rye notes, wood, plum, and fig.  Some yeast bite and substantial hop bitterness.  Medium-plus bodied and rather lively on the mouthfeel.  A tasty and unique beer overall.

Bottle 750ml. @ PBF 2011Clear light dark brown amber colour with a large to huge, frothy, good lacing, fully lasting, light beige head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, caramel, chocolate, rye, wood, berry - raisin - plum - prune. Flavour is light heavy sweet, light acidic and moderate bitter with a average to long duration, plum - raisin sour. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20110702]

Bottle, 1 pt 9.4 fl oz, thanks to Gusgus!Sampled on July 16, 2011Dark brown color, tan head. Acidic, sweet, malty scent. Acidic, malty, apple taste. Medium mouthfeel, low bitterness.Not something IÂ’d buy again right off.

Bottle. Dark brown color. Very low carbonation. Slight sour, almost funky aroma. Grainy with pronounced rye aroma, very much like sourdough ryebread. Slightly roasted and toasted aroma with hints of old cheese.
Flavor is dry and toasty, followed by silky grainy malt, a hint of mint and finally a somewhat phenolic belgianesque sour finish. Medium to high bitterness. Very intriguing beer, but the sour toasted malts together with phenols and obvious bitterness makes for a difficult drinking experience.

Thanks kiefdog for the share.  Pours opaque dark brown with a fluffy tan head.  Nose is vinegar, cocoa, spices, oak, red grapes, vinous quality, and tartness.  Flavor is similar with tartness and cocoa, with red wine and oak with some background tart cherries.  Medium in body and just a great sour saison.

Bottled 650ml (PBF)
Dark brown color, small steady off-white head, lace. Ryeish and cardboardish aroma. Slightly tart, ryeish grainy, caramelly. Too harsh bready finish to be enjoyable, although it is quite complex brew.
Bottled (thanks after4ever!). Ruby colour, small off-white head. Aroma is raisins, alcohol, sweet grains and some mild notes of spices. Flavour is rye, malts, alcohol, grains and mild notes.

A steady pour into my large Tripel Karmeliet tulip produces a four finger thick, glass filling, lightly browned, dark tan colored head that leaves a fair amount of lacing on the sides of my glass.  The beer is a dark brown color that shows a viscous texture to it by the carbonation bubbles that struggle to swim through it.  The aroma smells a little tart and somewhat fruity that is backed by a grainy / malty character.  The beer has a brown cracker aromatic note to it as well as a husk-like, thrushed grain, or even straw like character to it towards the finish.  There is a spiciness here that seems mostly contributed by the yeast character (peppery with a touch of ginger even), but the rye and dark grain character also subtly influences this as does a touch  of spicy hop character.  The fruitiness, especially as it warms, reminds me of a tart / floral plum and even with a touch of Macintosh apple like aromatics.  The grain character and yeast definitely has a musty character and a brown toasted grain starts to come out as the beer warms up.

The viscous quality of this beer has held in the carbonation quite well and it effervesces quite a bit as it rolls across the tongue.  There is a definite tartness to this beer, though it isnÂ’t really big (i.e. this is not a sour beer by any means), and it accentuates the fruitiness that is in the flavor; the fruit character reminds me of plums (though not as complex as in the aroma) and perhaps a touch of tart raisin.  As the beer warms up a bit more a a complex grain character starts to come out in the finish; it is a bit spicy, sort of reminds me of toasted hay, perhaps a hint of bitter cocoa, and it definitely reminds me of spicy, toasty, whole grain character (and even rye specifically).  Despite have a fair amount of viscousness to it, this beer is still quite quaffable and light.  There is an herbal character from the hops that, towards the finish, melts into the tartness somehow; it has a touch of pine like character to it, perhaps a hint of rosemary and a light, but firm bitterness as well.  Flavors of tamarind are also found here.

This is a very nice beer; I really enjoy this interpretive Saison from upright, the rye and the darker malt character really takes this in a great direction.  It may not be a unique direction, but it is certainly well executed and quite tasty in the glass.  Even though I have liked this from the beginning, it is still growing on me more as it warms up and I work my way through this beer.  This is definitely my favorite upright beer of the few I have tried so far.
Draft in the tasting room.  Very dark brown color, brown head.  Aroma of Sour prunes and plums on rye bread.  Taste has raisins, dates, prunes.  Amazing.

750mL bottle.  Poured deep cola brown with a tall, darker tan head.. set up nicely in the glass.  The aroma picked up chocolate, rye, and earthy notes with accents of sage and oak.. warm caramel and molasses also showed.. hints of tanginess around the edges of the nose.. very much enjoyed it.  The flavor found chocolate, caramel, and rye at the core with dry earth, black pepper, and caraway around.. finished dry and spicy, but with a fine malt complement.  Medium-bodied, dry, and scratchy on the palate with some sharp carbonation.. a bit too dense at times.  Very solid brew!

Dark garnet pour with a giant tan head that slowly fades.  Probably a little over carbonated but not a gusher or anything think dedolle.  Aroma is toffee, peppery spice and Papaya.  Caramel, toffee, light chocolate, white pepper and pineapple.  Interesting for sure not my favorite by any stretch.  Really dry finish

Champagne bottle served in a Duvel tulip. Deep dark amber-brown color. Massive khaki-orange head. Solid retention and lace. Perfection. Nose of rye malt, earth, cherry, wood, and pinot noir. Light sour flavor. Medium body, beaucoup carbonation, ultra creamy mouthfeel, and a soft tart, dry finish. Wow! I thought Seven was my favorite. I might have to change that.
Bottle courtesy of riversideAK.  Pours ruby red with a tan head.  Smells of sweet rye, some subtle fruity hints, sage, floral.  Tastes of cherries, tart, light sourness, funk finish.

750 mL bottle. Poured into Duvel tulip. 

APPEARANCE:

Pours deep amber copper with a ruby hue. Hazy. 

Huge creamy head is 3+ fingers, light beige, and has lengthy retention. Head settles in a rocky fashion and leaves some patches of lacing. 

Noticeably rapid carbonation trail rising from center of bottom of glass. 

AROMA: Tart red fruit (pomegranate, raspberry, and cherry). Sour. Saison yeast. Wet dead leaves (ie, rainy Fall day). Tree-like earthiness; similar to a woody aroma. Faint peppery spice. Some light chalkiness. Extremely faint vanilla bean/white chocolate. The chocolate and caramel aromas described on bottle do come out as it warms up a bit, though only subtly - even then, they are largely masked by the overall tartness. 

TASTE: Tart with some tart bitterness. Tangy. Quite puckering. Subtle stone-like earthiness. Tart red fruit, primarily pomegranate; as well as some subtle cherry. Taste is like eating pomegranate and then once the fruit is eaten off the seed, chewing the seed to get a lengthy bitter finish. 

Some faint vanilla as well as even more subtle wood on back of palate. 

Faint metallic taste on finish. 

Finish is more tart bitterness. 

Have to work quite hard to discern chocolate and caramel notes on palate Â– they appear on back of palate when it warms up a bit; even then, are largely masked by overall tartness and bitterness. 

MOUTH FEEL: Nice carbonation. Medium bodied. Quite smooth for such a puckering beer. Fairly dry.

OVERALL: Primarily tart and bitter. Much more tart than expected. Ok, though expected more from this beer; in particular, expected more saison-like qualities. Unable to pick out much of the rye characteristics in the taste behind all the tartness. Rustic. Would pair well with hard cheeses, though unlikely that would want to pair this with charcuterie or cooked red meat.

My Bottom Line:
Blackberry fruitiness evolves into tartness, while pickle-like vinegar notes and bubbly, detached carbonation point to a building infection...

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A creamy head of foam tops the mahogany-hued brown.
-The commercial description says "chocolate and caramel"... There was nothing remotely close to these flavors, so, with the vinegary flavors, I presume something went awry with this bottle and/or batch.

-Bready notes emerge from the malt signature, alongside roasted flakes.
-Candied cherries appear here and there.

In long: Nose of dusty attic, salad croutons, dry rye bread.  Taste of melba toasts, seeds, rustic yeast, grainy malts, dust, milk chocolate, earth, coal.  Overall the beer came through as rather Â“roughÂ”.  There was a rustic Saison yeast twist but this is a bad interpretation of the style.  As a dirty yeasty ale it is ok, as a Saison it fails.  Saisons should be session beers.  The more of those dark Saisons I try, the more I think they make as much sense as a Â“Learn to Read in 21 daysÂ” book.

750ml bottle.  Pouring a mostly clear, dark cherrywood color, the body lofts up a billowing head of spongy, khaki colored froth.  The steadfast foam slowly gives way to solid walls of lacing that break apart into organic, clumpy splotches and flares.  Aromas are dry and spicy, showing notes of cola, dehydrated figs, and baked rye bread in the malt base, accentuated with notes of caraway seed, chicory, oily orange peel, and some minty saison yeast.  A faint hint of airy, whipped cream softens all the sharp edges. Flavors are similarly structured, again quite dry, with just a bit of cola and roasted caramel sweetness there to break up the reign of spicy rye, aged citrus hops, and peppery, minty Belgian yeast.  Figgy fruit sugars intensify on the finish, leaving behind a sweet aftertaste. The palate, while only moderate in substance, is perfectly balanced in terms of carbonation, and is delectably dry until after the swallow.  ItÂ’s alltogether quite drinkable and pleasing, even on a 96 degree day on Captiva Island, which is where I find myself today. Upright continues to impress me in almost all that they do.
